children.subject: I don't think a single B+ in 70 is an issue, and course staff will accommodate the unique circumstances of this semester when making offers/ So if you take everything P/NP, I don't think you have to worry too much

In EE127, I think Ranade recently posted:

"I've received a lot of questions from students around the decision to P/NP this and other classes. I'm writing this post to encourage you to make the decision that is least stressful for you; I strongly believe there is no value judgement associated with whether a student choose to take a letter grade in some, all or none of their classes. 

The P/NP versus letter grading option is meant to reduce student stress. So you should make whatever decision reduces your stress the most. This does NOT have to be the same across all your courses. If getting a letter grade in some courses and P/NP-ing others makes you less stressed, do that. 

When graduate schools and job interviewers are looking at your transcript, they are not going to be looking specifically at how you did this semester, they will be looking overall. People will just disregard this semester as an anomalous semester and will focus on your other grades as reflecting your performance. Everyone knows that this semester was completely unprecedented.

Hope this helps. The important thing is to not stress over this decision, there is no "better" decision."

I'm not in this course but have seen the post.
I also have only seen posts about grading all or PNPing all

However, Shewchuk wrote earlier: 

"P/NP vs. letter grades: For the vast majority of you, I recommend sticking with P/NP this semester. The university has offered you a great chance to reduce your stress this semester, and you should take it. There are few circumstances under which a letter grade will buy you anything of value in your future. Your overall GPA might affect your first job, but won't affect your second.

The main exceptions, people who perhaps should opt for letter grades, fall into two categories. One category is geniuses who get A's with little effort; I won't say more about them. The second category is those of you who are specifically shooting for graduate work specifically in machine learning, or a high-level job specifically in machine learning; for you, having an A in 189 might make a difference, though it won't matter as much as your overall GPA. (If you're in 289A, it shouldn't matter at all.) However, keep in mind that if some of your Spring 2020 transcript grades are A's and some are P's, readers might assume that the P's aren't good grades; it's probably wiser to do all P/NP or all letter grades."

These responses just prove that professors and people on admission committees are human, with their own biases and views of the admission process.  Someone on an admission committee may favor all letter grades, while another might not care if you're P/NPing. In the end, it's really a guessing game. Of course, all A's would be ideal in all cases, but any other case could have pros and cons depending on who is reviewing your application.
I feel like PNP all is ok though in general, I just got interested in a professor suggesting taking some graded

Yes, it won't make your application look worse. But if you have decent grades, maybe a mixture of B+, A-, and A, that may look better than all P/NP depending on who's reviewing your application.

That being said, PNP wouldn't make your application look worse, it just won't make it look better if that makes sense.
As someone who would really like to take a mix of graded and P/NP, that Ranade post helps a lot, Helix.

<md>Here's a student response endorsed by Shewchuk:
"If I were a reader looking at someone's Spring 2020 transcript, this would probably be my logic flow:
If you have entirely PNP for Sp20, I would assume you were impacted by COVID-19 pretty heavily like most people, and you subscribed to the default PNP to reduce your stress and to help you cope with the situation. I would probably just omit the Sp20 grades from my admittance criteria if all grades were PNP and give you the benefit of a doubt because this is a global crisis and nobody should be penalized for it.

If you have, say the following grades for Sp20: A, P, P, A-, P, I would assume that you were trying to be clever by only opting into letter grades for the classes you did well in, and PNP'd the classes that you did poorly in--you perhaps were trying to maximize your GPA by taking advantage of the relaxed PNP standards. And for this, I would assume your PNP grades would in fact have been bad grades and you were trying to exploit the situation, which I may inherently penalize you for.

Not saying that everyone who partially PNPs classes is trying to exploit the situation, but this is probably how many readers/admittance people would interpret it. If you just do the default PNP, I think most readers will apply some sensitivity and understanding to the situation, and assume you were impacted by the crisis and not penalize you for that. Whereas if you partially PNP, some readers might either 1) assume you were trying to exploit the global crisis or b) that your PNP grades were bad grades (which is probably true, let's be real).

This is why I think it makes sense to either take all classes for a grade, or all classes for PNP. And I really don't think it is very likely that readers will penalize you for choosing the PNP option. The readers are humans too and they also lived through this incredibly stressful crisis, so I would be willing to bet that they will have great humility for Sp20 and not penalize anyone for PNP grades.

If you are worried about PNPing 189 because you want to apply to a masters program, but you are finding it very difficult to perform well under the circumstances, I would just take it PNP and in your application you could explain the situation and why it was difficult for you and why you PNPd everything. If you do that, a reader is highly unlikely to penalize you for PNP, in my opinion. If you are just honest and real about the situation, you probably won't get penalized for it. Whereas if you try to be sneaky and selectively PNP, the reader will likely be less understanding."</md>

The class I didn’t do well on is CS188, and it’s a field I would want to enter along with ML, and I don’t really think getting a B+ is a good idea for this class(I’m A- now, adjusting to home was really rough and the 188 exams are hard enough).

And on the midterm, did beneath what I need on the final for an A-, that being said I definitely haven’t abandoned the course but home adjustment is very rough. I thought I felt secure about my decisions (pnp all do research well for a paper) but Ranade is making me rethink again... And also the comment about decent grades three above

<md>I don't think a B+ in 70 will make or break your application for the masters. That being said, do you have a source to point to for p/np some and grading others? I've only seen posts about grading all vs p/np all for grad school.</md>

history.content:
I know there might've been many similar posts about grades, but I was wondering about my situation. I am a second year who got a B+ in one lower div (70) and all As in other courses. I have strong extracurriculars (research, course involvement), and was looking to use my grades from this semester to cover the B+ (which I wasn't at all expecting), but my home situation is not as ideal for studying as school and is causing me to consider pnping all of my courses since I did not too well on a midterm for a seemingly important upper div (not 170), and I was told to either pnp all or grade all for masters. I'm sending applications in to some programs (not higher education but potentially some programs) next year and was wondering how I should feel about this. I may get involved in course staff next semester in a course I'm taking this semester, so that can help, but still. 

I've also been reading recently that pnp for some and grading some is ok? What is the best way for me to demonstrate that I've done anything meaningful for the first part of this semester?
history.subject: Grade Advice
